title: All About Bhutan
description: Explore the rich cultural heritage, breathtaking nature, and unforgettable travel experiences in Bhutan.

sections.title: History
sections.content: Bhutan's recorded history begins in the 8th century when Guru Padmasambhava introduced Buddhism. It was unified in the 17th century under Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. The country transitioned to a constitutional monarchy in 2008.

sections.title: Nature
sections.content: Bhutan is a biodiversity hotspot with 70% forest cover. National parks and sanctuaries protect species like the snow leopard, takin, golden langur, and black-necked crane.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Located in the Eastern Himalayas, Bhutan features high mountains, lush valleys, and rivers. The altitude varies from 200m in the south to over 7,000m in the north.

sections.title: Architecture
sections.content: Bhutan’s architecture, featuring Dzongs, Lhakhangs, Goenpas, chortens, palaces, bridges, and vernacular housing, embodies the nation’s rich cultural heritage. These structures blend engineering excellence with aesthetic beauty.

sections.title: Travel Distances
sections.content: Except for Gasa district, Bhutan’s 20 districts have road access despite challenging terrain. Roads are winding with frequent bends, steep slopes, and slow average speeds around 30 km/h. However, the journey offers stunning mountain, jungle, village, and monastery views.

sections.title: Arts and Crafts
sections.content: Bhutan’s arts and crafts, integral to its tradition and spiritual life, interpret widely held values and beliefs rather than abstract beauty. This subjective process reflects a strong moral sense and often symbolizes the timeless battle of good versus evil.
